Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: Yeah.

Speaker: Speaker 4 (College Student)
Utterance: That's what it's called.

Utterance: Yeah.

Utterance: yeah, I haven't heard of it before.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: It describes something in AI, which is that things that are really intuitive and easy for humans, are actually really difficult to build into AI systems.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And on the flip side, picking up an object, really simple for people, but it's actually really difficult to build that into robotic systems.

Utterance: I wasn't so used to the aspect of, like, teaching computer how to do stuff.

Speaker: Speaker 4 (College Student)

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)

Utterance: I feel like that might be a problem.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: So you can think of robotics as having two core components.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: One is perception, being able to see and feel and so forth, and action, where the robot actually figures out how to move its arm.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And both components are really essential, and both components are quite difficult.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: If you train a perception system independently of how to choose actions, then it might make errors in a way that mess up the system that selects actions.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And so if you instead try to train these two systems together, to have it learn perception action for the goal of solving these different tasks, then the robot can be more successful.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: One thing that's really difficult about robotics is, there actually isn't that much data of robots in the world.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: On the internet, there's all sorts of text data, all sorts of image data that people upload and write.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: But there isn't a lot of data of doing a simple thing, like tying your shoe, for example, because it's so basic.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: One challenge is even just getting data sets that allow us to teach robots to do these simple kinds of tasks.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And by doing that, we might be able to overcome some of the challenges of Moravec's paradox.

Speaker: Speaker 4 (College Student)
Utterance: What are some common algorithms that are used in these types of techniques as the robot is learning?

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: Deep learning is a common toolbox for addressing some of these challenges, because it allows us to leverage large data sets.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And so, deep learning is basically, corresponds to methods for training these artificial neural networks.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: Another common method that comes up is reinforcement learning.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: A third kind of algorithm is meta learning algorithms.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And these algorithms learn not just from the most recent experience on the current task, but leverage experience from other task in the past.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: And they're not just completely separate.

Speaker: Speaker 1 (Chelsea Finn)
Utterance: We can combine the aspects of these algorithms into a single method that gets the benefits of each of them.
